entities.entity_description: A naturally occurring "body-own" anti-inflammatory compound cited as effective and safe against influenza and the common cold; described as a natural compound for health management; identified in the text as a PPARα agonist; reported to activate and desensitize TRPV1 channels in sensory neurons; reported to counteract substance P–induced mast cell activation in vitro by stimulating diacylglycerol lipase activity; subject of receptor-search studies.
Ion channel protein in sensory neurons reported to be activated and desensitized by the PPARα agonist palmitoylethanolamide.
A receptor (PPARα) targeted by palmitoylethanolamide, which is described in the text as a PPARα agonist.

An enzyme whose activity is reported to be stimulated by palmitoylethanolamide; stimulation of this enzyme by palmitoylethanolamide is reported to counteract substance P–induced mast cell activation in vitro.
A signaling molecule cited in the text as inducing mast cell activation; palmitoylethanolamide is reported to counteract substance P–induced mast cell activation in vitro.
An in vitro phenomenon induced by substance P and reported to be counteracted by palmitoylethanolamide via stimulation of diacylglycerol lipase activity.
Referenced as the subject of a 2002 publication by Ueda N. (title: "Endocannabinoid hydrolases").
An experimental high-fat diet specified as having a high C18:0/C16:0 ratio; reported by Wang et al. to induce worse metabolic and transcriptomic profiles in C57BL/6 mice.
entities.entity_name: High-Fat Diet With High C18:0/C16:0 Ratio

entities.entity_description: The ratio of C18:0 to C16:0 fatty acids used as a parameter in the cited high-fat diet; a high C18:0/C16:0 ratio in the diet was associated with worse metabolic and transcriptomic profiles in C57BL/6 mice (Wang et al.).
A common laboratory mouse strain (C57BL/6) in which Wang et al. reported that a high-fat diet with a high C18:0/C16:0 ratio induced worse metabolic and transcriptomic profiles.
Metabolic and transcriptomic readouts that were reported to be worsened in C57BL/6 mice fed a high-fat diet with a high C18:0/C16:0 ratio (Wang et al.).
Fatty acids studied by Donnelly et al. as being stored in the liver and secreted via lipoproteins in patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.
The organ in which fatty acids are reported to be stored and from which they are secreted via lipoproteins in patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (Donnelly et al.).
Particles via which fatty acids are reported to be secreted from the liver in patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (described in Donnelly et al.).
A disease context (nonalcoholic fatty liver disease) in which sources of fatty acids stored in the liver and secreted via lipoproteins were examined.
A disease listed in the text as one against which palmitoylethanolamide was reported to be effective and safe (Keppel Hesselink et al.).
A disease (common cold) listed in the text as one against which palmitoylethanolamide was reported to be effective and safe (Keppel Hesselink et al.).
The putative receptor for palmitoylethanolamide that was the subject of a search described by LoVerme et al. (2005) in the cited literature.

relationships.relationship_description: Palmitoylethanolamide is reported to be effective and safe against influenza.
Palmitoylethanolamide is reported to be effective and safe against the common cold.
Palmitoylethanolamide is described in the text as a PPARα agonist (i.e., it acts on PPARα).
The PPARα agonist palmitoylethanolamide is reported to activate and desensitize TRPV1 channels in sensory neurons.
Palmitoylethanolamide is reported to stimulate diacylglycerol lipase activity.
Palmitoylethanolamide is reported to counteract substance P–induced mast cell activation in vitro.
Substance P is reported to induce mast cell activation (the activation that palmitoylethanolamide counteracts).
Stimulation of diacylglycerol lipase activity by palmitoylethanolamide is reported to mediate the counteraction of substance P–induced mast cell activation.
A high-fat diet with a high C18:0/C16:0 ratio is reported to induce worse metabolic and transcriptomic profiles.
relationships.source_entity: High-Fat Diet With High C18:0/C16:0 Ratio

relationships.relationship_description: The worsened metabolic and transcriptomic profiles were observed in C57BL/6 mice according to the cited study.
Fatty acids are reported to be stored in the liver (study context: patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease).
Fatty acids are reported to be secreted via lipoproteins.
Sources of fatty acids stored in the liver and secreted via lipoproteins were examined in patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (linking fatty acids to the disease context).
LoVerme et al. conducted a search for the palmitoylethanolamide receptor (publication subject linked to the receptor).
